metadata.titleEn: Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (leaf area index of Mixed forest station, 2020)
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the LAI measurements from the Sidaoqiao in the downstream of the Heihe integrated observatory network from July 26 to October 20 in 2020. The site was located in Ejina Banner in Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region. The elevation is 870 m. There are 1 observation samples, around Mixed forest station (101.1335E, 41.9903N), which is about 30 m×30 m in size. Five sub-canopy nodes and one above-canopy node are arranged in each sample. 
The data is obtained from LAINet measurements; the four-steps are performed to obtain LAI: the raw data is light quantum (level 0); the daily LAI can be obtained using the software LAInet (level 1); further the invalid and null values are screened and using the 7 days moving averaged method to obtain the processed LAI (level 2); for the multi LAINet nodes observation, the averaged LAI of the nodes area is the final LAI (level 3).
The released data are the post processed LAI products and stored using *.xls format.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Qu et al. (2014) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to measure leaf area index in mixed forest stands?
Example.Answer: The leaf area index in mixed forest stands is measured using a wireless sensor network called LAINet. This method involves automatic data collection of light measurements at various nodes, both below and above the forest canopy, which are then processed to calculate daily leaf area index values.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in data collection for oasis–desert ecosystems?
Example.Answer: A challenge in data collection for oasis–desert ecosystems is dealing with the ecological degradation in arid inland river basins, such as the drying up of rivers, degradation of vegetation, and intensified desertification, which complicates long-term environmental monitoring.

Example.Question: Could you give an example of a dataset that includes energy, water vapor, and carbon flux observations in an oasis–desert area?
Example.Answer: An example of such a dataset comprises long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, along with hydrometeorological, vegetation, and soil parameters from the middle and lower reaches of the HRB in western China, available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Definition.Question: What does 'eddy covariance system' mean in terms of collecting energy and carbon flux data?
Definition.Answer: An 'eddy covariance system' is a method used to measure and analyze turbulent fluxes of energy, water vapor, and carbon dioxide between the surface and the atmosphere. In the context of the field, it involves acquiring half-hourly turbulent flux data to study energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in oasis–desert ecosystems, supporting long-term ecological observations.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of 'oasis–desert system' in environmental and socioeconomic research?
Definition.Answer: The 'oasis–desert system' is significant in research as it plays a crucial role in maintaining ecological stability and agricultural productivity in arid and semi-arid regions. It supports the majority of the population in these areas and is critical for achieving sustainable development goals, particularly in understanding and balancing energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges to protect ecological security and support socioeconomic development.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods for leaf area index using wireless sensor networks compare to those used for energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes in oasis-desert systems?
Comparison.Answer: The data collection for leaf area index involves a wireless sensor network (LAINet) that automatically gathers light data at various nodes, while the energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes are collected using an eddy covariance system and scintillometer, supplemented by automatic weather stations for hydrometeorological data.

Comparison.Question: How do the data processing techniques for leaf area index compare to those for energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange datasets in terms of handling environmental variability and data quality control?
Comparison.Answer: Leaf area index data processing involves handling raw light data, calculating daily indices, and applying a 7-day moving average to mitigate weather variability. In contrast, energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange datasets require quality control procedures that include data processing and archiving, addressing different types of environmental variability through a systematic approach.

Interpretation.Question: What are the main challenges faced in maintaining long-term data collection on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges include ecological degradation such as drying rivers and vegetation loss, land desertification, and dust storms, particularly in arid regions like those along the Silk Road. These environmental issues can disrupt data collection and affect the stability and reliability of the observations.

Interpretation.Question: What methodological approaches are essential for ensuring the quality and reliability of hydrometeorological data in inland river basins?
Interpretation.Answer: Using automatic weather stations to collect data every 10 minutes and employing a robust quality control procedure that includes data processing, archiving, and sharing are crucial. Supplementary data on vegetation and soil parameters also support the integrity of the dataset.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of using long-term observational datasets in understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using long-term observational datasets allows for a quantitative understanding of the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems. This understanding is crucial for recognizing oasis–desert interactions, protecting ecological stability, and supporting socioeconomic development. Long-term data are indispensable for achieving sustainable oasis development and meeting carbon peaking and neutrality goals.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the presence of ecological environment degradation challenges, like drying rivers and lakes, influence the data collection methods in inland river basins of arid regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Ecological degradation challenges such as drying rivers and lakes necessitate a comprehensive and systematic data collection approach that includes hydrometeorological data and vegetation and soil parameters. This approach allows for the monitoring of environmental changes and supports efforts to manage and mitigate the impacts of such degradation in inland river basins.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary intention behind collecting and processing leaf area index (LAI) data in mixed forest stations using a wireless sensor network?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary intention is to understand the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange processes in oasis–desert ecosystems to support ecological stability and sustainable development. The processed LAI data helps achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in these areas.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it essential to maintain long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Long-term observations are crucial for quantitatively understanding oasis–desert interactions, which significantly impact ecological stability and socioeconomic development. This understanding is key to maintaining the balance between oasis and desert systems for sustainable oasis development.

Goal Orientation.Question: What motivates the integration of hydrometeorological data and vegetation parameters in observational datasets for oasis–desert systems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Integrating hydrometeorological data and vegetation parameters aims to comprehensively assess the energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, which are fundamental to protecting ecological security and ensuring sustainable development in arid and semiarid regions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are the original observational data from a wireless sensor network processed to ensure the accuracy and reliability of the leaf area index measurements?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The original observational data, initially in a Level0 format consisting of light intensity data captured hourly at each node, are processed using specialized software to compute daily LAI values (Level1). Invalid values are identified and filled, and a 7-day moving average is employed to mitigate the influence of weather changes on LAI calculations (Level2). For multiple nodes within an observation sub-area, the mean value of the nodes is used as the final observation value (Level3).

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods are used to integrate auxiliary data, such as vegetation and soil parameters, into the observational datasets of oasis–desert systems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Auxiliary data involving vegetation and soil parameters are integrated into the observational datasets by supplementing the primary data collection process, which includes hydrometeorological and flux data. This integration ensures a comprehensive dataset that supports understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange dynamics in oasis–desert ecosystems.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the comprehensive collection and processing of leaf area index (LAI) data in mixed forest stations within arid regions?
Enablement.Answer: The use of the Leaf Area Index Wireless Sensor Network (LAINet) enables comprehensive data collection and processing by automatically obtaining light data from multiple nodes every hour. The LAINet software processes this data into daily LAI values, identifies and fills invalid data, and applies a 7-day moving average to mitigate weather variations.

Enablement.Question: How do long-term observational datasets facilitate the understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Enablement.Answer: Long-term observational datasets, including energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes, alongside auxiliary data on hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters, provide a quantitative understanding of ecosystem interactions. These datasets, collected using eddy covariance systems and automatic weather stations, support ecological stability and sustainable development goals.

Enablement.Question: What challenges are faced in maintaining data quality and continuity in inland river basins experiencing ecological degradation?
Enablement.Answer: Inland river basins face challenges such as river and lake drying, vegetation degradation, land desertification, and frequent dust storms. These environmental issues can disrupt data collection and impact the quality and continuity of datasets necessary for understanding ecological processes in arid and semiarid regions.

Expectation.Question: Why might long-term observations be indispensable for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Expectation.Answer: Long-term observations are crucial to achieve a quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas. They are significant for recognizing oasis–desert interactions and protecting the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases. This understanding supports the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area, which are critical for ecological security and sustainable development.

Expectation.Question: What challenges might arise when collecting data in inland river basins within arid and semiarid regions?
Expectation.Answer: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas face ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms. These challenges are especially prevalent in many inland river basins along the Silk Road, adding complexity to data collection efforts in these areas.

Expectation.Question: How might data collection methods be adapted to ensure the integrity of datasets comprising energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert systems?
Expectation.Answer: Data collection methods must involve a rigorous data processing and quality control procedure, which can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing. Observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems should include long-term energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes, as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters, to maintain the integrity of the datasets.

Judgmental.Question: How do you evaluate the effectiveness of using wireless sensor networks like LAINet for collecting leaf area index data in mixed forest environments?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of wireless sensor networks such as LAINet is highly effective for collecting detailed leaf area index data in mixed forest environments. These networks allow for automated, high-resolution temporal data collection, providing continuous daily and hourly illumination data. This enables more accurate LAI calculation by reducing weather-related variations through processing techniques like 7-day sliding averages. The structured data processing pipeline also ensures the data's reliability and usability.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges in maintaining data integrity and accuracy in long-term hydrometeorological observations in arid regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Long-term hydrometeorological observations in arid regions face challenges such as equipment durability in harsh conditions, data loss due to environmental factors, and the complexities of integrating data from various sources like eddy covariance systems and weather stations. Additionally, ensuring accurate calibration and maintenance of instruments is crucial to maintain data integrity. The variability of arid climates further complicates the interpretation of data, necessitating robust quality control and processing procedures.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways could expanding the network of land surface flux and meteorological stations enhance the understanding of oasis–desert ecosystem dynamics?
Judgmental.Answer: Expanding the network of land surface flux and meteorological stations could significantly enhance the understanding of oasis–desert ecosystem dynamics by providing more comprehensive spatial coverage and capturing diverse microclimatic variations. This would allow for a better understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes across different regions, improving the accuracy of ecological and climate models. Additionally, increased data points would facilitate more robust statistical analyses and improve the identification of patterns and trends in ecosystem interactions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe the data collection techniques used for observing leaf area index in mixed forest areas within arid regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection for leaf area index in mixed forest areas involves using a wireless sensor network, LAINet, to automatically record light data at each node daily and hourly. Observations are conducted in specific plots with designated canopy nodes, and the data undergo multiple processing stages to ensure accuracy and reliability.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explain the challenges faced in collecting and processing long-term hydrometeorological data within oasis–desert ecosystems.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges include ecological degradation such as drying rivers and lakes, vegetation degradation, and desertification. Collecting consistent and accurate data over long periods is difficult due to environmental variability and technical limitations in maintaining and operating measurement instruments in remote and harsh environments.

Request/Directive.Question: Please outline the key components of a dataset that captures energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas.
Request/Directive.Answer: A comprehensive dataset includes long-term measurements of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, hydrometeorological data such as radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles, gradients of air temperature and humidity, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, soil moisture profiles, and groundwater table data. Vegetation and soil parameters are also essential components of the dataset.
